course.subject: SOSC
course.name: Understanding Globalization
course.description: This course aims to help students learn theories and debates about globalization. The focus will be on economic, political, cultural, and social aspects of globalization. Students will discuss the process and impact of globalization in its various aspects.

reviews.author: 蔡可可
reviews.title: BAD GRADE and MUCH WORKLOAD
reviews.comment_content: There are 23 topics in this class,  and each topic the prof will use a long PPT to explain it and give examples. Topics cover many concepts of China and the relationship between China and other countries, especially America and the third world countries. But it's hard to understand the class if you don't preview the ppt, and that costs around 2-3 hours pre day(after class).
reviews.comment_teaching: David's class is okay and he likes to make jokes.
reviews.comment_grading:
Well. There are a midterm, a group project and a final.

There are 10% participation, you need to ask questions in class and the TA will write down your name.

Midterm is MC. But it is really difficult. It covers the reading materials and PPTs. Reading materials are too many(usually 20-70 pages after EVERY class!!), so it's hard for you to read all of them. But the exam covers every details in them, like "which one is not the perspective that xxx holds". Plus, you must memorize the PPT carefully，many MCs are completely the same with the ppt pages. The mean is low and I got the mean grade--43/100

The group project is also really hard. The group of 5-6 people  need to submit 12-15 pages paper and take a presentation in front of the class. The topic must relates to China study.

Final contains 2 short essays. There are 4-6 questions in one big topic and the prof only give us 1 hour to complete two topics. The topics are more difficult than the topics he taught in class. If you listen to him carefully and read all the materials, you may feel a little bit relieved. Otherwise, you can write nothing but bullshit.

I don't know my grades of group project and final. I got a  C finally. But I devoted most of my time in studying this course. Most of my group mates got C, their midterm grades all higher than the mean.
reviews.comment_workload:
REALLY HEAVY.
See what I write in the grading part.

reviews.author: vault34overseer
reviews.comment_content: 一個對於全球化嘅基本介紹,雖然佢話政治,經濟,社會同文化嘅全球化都會講,但唔知係咪因為佢研究興趣係政治經濟學嘅關係,所以個重點會喺經濟度,跟住先到政治,社會同文化講得有限.因為要講嘅內容太多,再加上所牽涉嘅學科太廣,所以佢其實講得唔深入。但係呢堂係輕鬆嘅,亦都會增進到世界視野.特別建議商學院嘅學生嚟學,因為同佢地學到嘅內容都幾有關係。
reviews.comment_teaching: 靚女教授,小息嘅時候會播吓kpop.大致上輕鬆,氣都好嘅.佢啲英文會有啲韓國口音,但係都係清楚嘅.不過就要自已上堂填powerpoint上面啲空格,全部都係重要內容,唔建議走堂
reviews.comment_grading:
Parti15%
Quiz15%
midterm35%mc
final35%mc(可以寫paper代替)

小弟midterm2.3 sd quiz 1.6sd A+
reviews.comment_workload:
輕鬆冇assigment
但係建議睇reading有問題會喺裡面出

reviews.author: Kyile_00
reviews.comment_content: The course contain two parts. Parts I focus on the globalization of capital, production, trade, technology, energy and human resources, its impact on society, labor and politics, and how it generates recurrent economic crises, all within the global economic structure. Part II will apply these perspectives on globalization to China’s opening.
reviews.comment_teaching: David is quite nice. He loves interacting with students. His lectures are quite clear and easy to understand. He invites guests to teach certain topics. There are 5 mins break in class!
reviews.comment_grading: The grade is very good. It is not hard to get an A if u have read the required readings. I ended up with A-.
reviews.comment_workload: the workload is not heavy. There is one midterm, one final and a group project. The midterm included MC only. Final is an essay exam. Midterm and final exams will include the materials/contents covered in lectures and readings.

reviews.author: ykykong
reviews.title: stupid course
reviews.comment_content: boring content, very broad but no concrete and useful content for my future studies
reviews.comment_teaching: hea professor, no passion at all, i studied this course obviously because its compulsory to GCS students. She only talks in one tone,
reviews.comment_grading: although the exam was really hard for me, i still managed to get a B for my final grade, i don't know why, maybe because everyone did poorly.
reviews.comment_workload:
Workload is fine, as i remember, one midterm and one final and also one group project. Selecting good group mates are very important for this course.

There are a lot of readings but the professor is going to announce which pages of the textbook is important for the exams JUST one week before the exam, LOL better ask friends who have studied this course for it.

Also she played loads of videos to fill the lesson time (so she didn't have to teach) and she left the classroom when it was playing (I don't think people will play full attention to watch many of them leave early )

Also the readings are many, I dont think students can go over them before exam.

reviews.author: michael04
reviews.title: An Interesting Course with Broad Content
reviews.comment_content:
1. History of Globalization
2. International Trade
3. Multinational Corporations & Global Supply Chains
4. International Migration
5. International Development (I. Prosperity and Poverty; II. Globalization  and Economic Inequality)
6. Globalization and Peace
7. Globalization and Democracy
8. Globalization and the Coronavirus Pandemic
reviews.comment_teaching: Nice professor who is willing to discuss and interact with students on different course topics.
reviews.comment_grading:
• Participation (25%): Submit discussion questions about the weekly reading assignments. Respond to the instructor during classes.

• Response Paper (25%): ONE response paper reacting to one of the
weekly assigned readings. Approximately 5 pages (Times
New Roman, 12-point font, double spaced).

• Final Exam (50%): Answer 2 long essay questions out of 3 in TWO hours.
*All make-upexams consist of long essay questions and an oral session.

My grade: A

Don’t know my exam and essay results.
reviews.comment_workload:
Acceptable

Weekly readings are very long in length. Workload depends on how you read.

Need time to write the essay (the ONLY assignment in this course). Better to start preparing earlier.

reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Zheng is very nice and willing to answer questions. She also likes to interact with students so there are a lot of opportunities to answer questions or share opinion in class. However, she always spent too much time for discussion leads to not enough time for lecture.

She is also very willing to listen to students' opinions about the course, and during Week 7/8 she sent out a questionnaire for students to give their opinions, and the professor made changes based on students' feedback. For example, fewer breakout rooms and pop-up quiz became pre-announced quiz.
reviews.comment_grading:
Absolute grading
Midterm Exam 25%
Final Exam 30%
Research Experience 20%
Class participation (Quiz & Discussion) 15%
Attendance 10%
reviews.comment_workload:
Quite a lot of essays and reading materials.

Each chapter has around 40 pages and you have to read 2 chapters each week .

reviews.author: SargeSmoke
reviews.title: Advantageous for those with Economics/Political background
reviews.comment_content:
Week 1: Introduction to the Course: Requirements, Objectives, and Scope
Week 2: History of Globalization
Week 3: Domestic Interests and International Trade
Week 4: State Power and International Trade
Week 5: Financial Globalization
Week 6: Financial Crises
Week 7: Globalization and Multinational Corporations
Week 8: International Migration
Week 9: Prosperity and Poverty
Week 10: Globalization and Economic Inequality
Week 11: Varieties of Capitalism
Week 12: The Backlash Against Globalization: Populism and Nationalism
Week 13: Globalization and the Coronavirus Pandemic
Week 14: Review Session

Content is essentially a mix of economics and politics (with a bit of history within the mix). Backgrounds in the first two disciplines can be useful as most of the economics aspect taught are content I have learnt before university. Certain content was pretty interesting but the difficulty increases the further into the course.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Dong Zhang, being new to HKUST as this was his first semester teaching at this university, is understandably not the most experienced professor. His accent is sometimes hard to understand, and he stutters quite a bit. Lectures consist of the professor reciting lecture slides off the board while occasionally providing some further insight. Certainly not the most invigorating class. He prompts students to ask him questions for further class discussions, and his answers to student's questions are elaborate but insightful.

You can certainly skip lectures and simply read off lecture materials to pass the course, but some slides are missing details which he answers in class. A lot of data and charts that are quite meaningless for the exam. Lectures are broadcasted on Zoom, but are not recorded, so do not expect yourself to come back and re-watch lectures later on.
reviews.comment_grading:
50% Final Exam
30% Essay Writing (Two Essays - 15% + 15%)
20% Class Participation

The final exam for this semester consisted of writing an essay response to two prompts out of three that were given. The exam is 2 hours long, online and open-book. A good understanding of the important concepts taught will help guide you through the exam, as well as knowledge about current events and reading materials as references to support your arguments. (Results were not published after exams)

Essay writing consists of writing two 3-5 page response papers to any two reading materials assigned to you every week. It is better to write your response as early as possible, as the sophistication of the reading material increases over-time. (I got an A for my first essay, the other essay's grade was not released)

To earn participation, contribute to class regularly by asking a "good" question (how/why questions) . Although attendance is not mandatory, if you want to earn participation grade it is better for you to attend and ask some questions. There is also a group debate on one reading material that can help boost your participation grade if you attend and contribute to the debate. (Grade was not published)

Overall, I got an A-.
reviews.comment_workload:
Workload is not the highest, only requiring you to read two reading materials in order to write two response papers. To excel at he course, you can read up on all the reading materials and keep up-to-date with current events. Preparation before exams is simple enough as it is open-book, just read up on past lecture notes and reading materials, while taking note of the most important concept from each lecture and understand it.

You are required to cite any outside sources used and reading materials for your final exam and your response papers.

reviews.comment_content:

reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof name is Dong Zhang. He is passionate about his teachings. It was his first year teaching at HKUST. His presentations are well structured and he reads from them most of the time. Most of the information needed for the exam will be on his slides so review will not be hard. However, a lot of his slides include graphs and statistics so take extra notes on those as they can be harder to understand when u look back on them. He will try hard to answer ur questions in class.

*** He does not upload class zoom meetings so make sure to attend the lessons.
reviews.comment_grading:
participation 20% - 1 class debate and rest are normal classes
2 reading responses 30%
final exam 50%
- choose 2 out of 3 essay questions
- essay structure is given and it's open book

final grade: A
reviews.comment_workload:
1 reading for every week. Some readings are quite long and hard to digest. I skipped some of the readings. You can use readings to answer final exam essay questions but extract the quotations before so you don't run out of time.

2 reading responses - try to go over the readings a while before it's due so u can pick ones that are easier to write about

reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor: Dong Zhang
He basically reads out the slides but is kind and willing to answer questions.
reviews.comment_grading:
participation 20%
response paper 30% (must write two papers so 15% for each)
final exam 50%
- not too hard to get a good grade if you enjoy writing essays
- participation is not based on attendance but on classroom participation
- final exam is in the same format as response paper; he will give you 3 essay topics and you can choose two out of three and write essay on it within the given time
reviews.comment_workload: Weekly reading materials are given but it is not necessary to read them all unless you want to understand every bit of detail. But you need to carefully read at least two of them to write the response paper.

reviews.author: OuO
reviews.title: This course is explicitly advantageous to SBM or SHSS students
reviews.comment_content:
Week 1: Introduction to the Course: Requirements, Objectives, and Scope
Week 2: History of Globalization
Week 3: Domestic Interests and International Trade
Week 4: State Power and International Trade
Week 5: Financial Globalization
Week 6: Financial Crises
Week 7: Globalization and Multinational Corporations
Week 8: International Migration
Week 9: Prosperity and Poverty
Week 10: Globalization and Economic Inequality
Week 11: Varieties of Capitalism
Week 12: The Backlash Against Globalization: Populism and Nationalism
Week 13: Globalization and the Coronavirus Pandemic
Week 14: Review Session

This course is quite interesting because it covers lots of information about globalization, like economic globalization, financial globalization and political globalization. It also covers many global society issues, like disparity between richer countries and poorer countries. This course is particularly advantageous to SBM or SHSS students because this course involves many economic, financial and social science concepts, such as opportunity cost, monetary policy, and society inequality etc.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Instructor(s): Dong, Zhong
Teaching Assistant(s): Bamboo Yunzhu REN

Prof. Zhang accent is not very good because he comes from mainland China. Sometimes I do not understand what he was talking during lessons. However, he was nice and willing to answer the questions raised from students.

I am unable to give too many comments to Bamboo because she did not appear in the face-to-face class. I think she needed to manage the situation of zoom class only😅
reviews.comment_grading:
Participation (20%): Students are expected to complete all required readings prior to each lecture. To secure a good participation grade, students are encouraged to actively contribute to the classroom discussion.
Response Paper (30%): Students will write TWO response papers reacting to reading materials.
Final Exam (50%): The final exam will cover all the course materials in the semester.

I got A- in the first response paper, but I do not know the score of remaining assessments (second response paper, exam and participation).
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is quite high because there is one reading for each week. It requires us to choose 2 readings from 12 weeks to write 2 response papers. Actually we have 1-2 weeks to finish 1 response paper, but most of readings are too long. The shortest reading contains 14 pages (around 6000 words). The longest reading contains almost 50 pages (around 20000 words).

We have an open-book exam in this course, we need to answer 2 questions in 2 hours. However, it requires to cite the sources from the internet if we need to use them. I do not have enough time to answer 2 questions because the time is really insufficient.

The format of answering one question is like that: "You only need to write a few paragraphs to answer one question. In the first paragraph, briefly introduce your arguments. Then use roughly three paragraphs to develop your arguments and use evidence (qualitative or quantitative) to support your arguments. You’d better use at least one paragraph to address counter-arguments or alternative explanations. In the end, summarize your arguments and draw a conclusion."

But he is very nice, welcome for all questions, so if you have any questions, just email him or make a reservation, he will explain it to you in mandarin to English. The ppt could provide a lot of information for you.

Response Paper (30%): Students will write TWO response papers reacting to reading materials.
Final Exam (50%): The final exam will cover all the course materials in the semester.

My grade: A-
I got an A for the 1st response paper.
The grade of the 2nd response paper and final exam are unknown.
reviews.comment_workload: Too high. You need to read all required reading and write 2 response papers to the reading in a semester. The essay he provided was quite long and hard to understand (the paper was 30+ pages). Each paper requires 5 pages and citation. Only one week to write the paper. The exam is open book, which is good.

- Really like the learning environment, the lesson was pretty interactive: The professor likes to ask us questions but no pressure!! (they're mostly concepts that we came across in secondary school)

reviews.author: cllamx
reviews.title: Dont choose this course to fulfill your CC (GCS students: you dont have a choice :0)
reviews.comment_content: Content covered from various aspects of globalization, including economic globalization (which covered a vast majority of the course as the prof is an expert on this topic), and a glimpse of cultural globalization. Honestly, it was more like a course discussing economic globalization, as the professor linked basically everything back to economics. My friends who had not studied Economics in high school found it quite difficult to understand the content, as the prof always throw some fancy theory names and they were quite complicated to understand for me too.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Zweig is a nice person, but honestly, his teaching is only so-so.  The ppt was so messy and he always referred the ppt of previous lectures so that I was so confused and I cant follow in class. Moreover, he likes to explain the same theory again and again with a whole bunch of examples in class that was not found in the ppt, and he spoke so fast that I couldn't follow at all. Ironically, the midterms and finals were mostly about the examples that he spoke in class, and if you miss a part or you can't understand of example, you're doomed in exams.
Moreover, don't be late for class, as you're gonna be scolded by him and he will keep questioning you why are you late (which implies that our lectures were always being distracted and lost focused lol)
reviews.comment_grading:
Not good grading at all (even though I've got an A range). Most of my friends fell into B- to C range.
If you are longing for a good grade, please buy the required textbook and finish the readings before every lecture. It helped me a lot in the midterms and finals. Enroll this course with your friends so that you could help each other in the group projects and have a higher chance of scoring a good grade.
reviews.comment_workload:
Fair workload for a 2000- level course

Midterm exam (25%)
Final exam (35%)
Group project (30%)
Class participation (10%)

The midterm and final exams will include the materials/contents covered in lectures and readings.

The Mid-term will be in a multiple choice format while the final exam will be an essay exam. The final exam will apply the theories and concepts of globalization to the China case and evaluate the overall impact of globalization on the world.

reviews.comment_workload:
there are one mid-term , one presentation and project and also one final.
The mid-term is MC format and a bit related to the reading yet the reading is really boring and long.

reviews.author: Yvette wang
reviews.comment_content: The content is quite difficult for the year 1 students to understand. Each class will cover a big topic such as globalization in education/financial system/energy, etc. The second half-semester will focus on the globalization of China. A lot of economic knowledge will be involved, it would be much easier if you have taken the basic macroeconomic.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. ZWEIG is one of the leading figures in this field and he teaches funny during the class. It's quite enjoyable to listen to his class despite the content is very hard.
reviews.comment_grading:
30% Midterm
30% Group paper
35% Final
5%   Participance in class

The grading is quite good, for he curves all the year 1 student first. I got B+ in the midterm, group paper and Final don't know. But I guess our group paper is fairly good and I wrote a lot in the final exam, so I got A- at last.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload of this course is extremely heavy compared to other courses. Every class you have to complete reading a chapter of the textbook(around 40 pages), and you need to preview the PPT(around 30 pages)  he will use in the next class, or it is hard to understand his class.

reviews.author: 科大薯仔
reviews.comment_content: Just take a look at the others' comments or search the syllabus of this course through GOOGLE. This course covers everything related to globalization, like the relationship between globalization and energy or other variables. A lot of theories were introduced.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor Zweig was not bad, he is the authority of Public Policy and Social science (in my opinion). In the lectures, he taught us a lot of advanced theories related to globalization. Yet, we were not allowed to talk during the lectures, otherwise, he would ask if we have any questions. The lectures were sometimes boring.
reviews.comment_grading:
To me, the grade was fair, as I didn't put much effort in this course, I skipped many lectures. Therefore, I received a D for my midterm. However, I guess my group paper was quite well written, so my grade turns out was not bad, the grade was in b range at last. For the final exam, owing to the political circumstances, it was changed to a 1-hour exam with three questions, you just have to pick two of them.

Another important thing is that there are 10% of participation mark for this course, you will receive some marks if you give out some meaningful questions, but I didn't ask any questions, so my mark for this part is zero.

Mark distribution:
Midterm exam (25%);
Final exam (35%);
Group project (30%);
Class participation (10%)
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload was a bit heavy if you would like to get good grades, as you have to read through the assigned readings every week. To get the participation scores, you have to familiarize yourself with the powerpoint slides and readings.

If you would just like to get average grades, you just need to revise one day before the midterm and final exam. Also, finish the group paper with your peers and make a good presentation (the presentation was canceled due to the cancellation of classes ).

reviews.author: ansonwhc
reviews.comment_content:
Class 1. Introduction to Globalization
Class 2. Theory 1: Globalization, International Structure and the State
Class 3. Theory 2. Measuring Globalization and Its Impact
PART II. FORMS OF GLOBALIZATION
Class 4. Globalization of Production, MNCs and Research and Development
Class 5. Globalization of Capital and Financial Crises
Class 6. Globalization of Trade and Transport
Class 7. Globalization and Inequality
Class 8. Globalization of Higher Education
Class 9. Globalization and the Politics of Energy
Class 10. Globalization of Human Capital: Migration of Skilled Workers
Class 11. Globalization of Cities: Culture, Life Styles and the Media
Class 12. Globalization and Politics: Democracy or Authoritarianism?
Class 13. Is Hong Kong a Global City?
Class 14. MID-TERM EXAM
PART III. CHINA AND GLOBALIZATION
Class 15. Globalization and. China’s Opening to the Outside World
Class 16. Globalization of Production and Trade in China
Class 17. Globalization of Capital in China
Class 18. Globalization, Income Distribution and China’s Developmental Strategy
Class 19. Globalization of Education, Talent and Migration
Class 20. China’s Global Search for Energy and Resources
Class 21. China Goes Global: Belt and Road Initiative
reviews.comment_teaching:
great teaching prof always relate concepts with current social issues
he loves students asking him questions/ try to answer his questions
reviews.comment_grading: Midterm exam (25%); Final exam (35%); Group project (30%); Class participation (10%)
reviews.comment_workload:
1-2 readings per class
prof requires students to take a look at the readings before going to lessons most of the answers for midterm can be found in readings
don't wait till the last minute to start those readings
1 group project about globalization

reviews.author: Yannes_lhc
reviews.comment_content: this course taught about the history of globalization, how companies / countries / talents changed in the era of globalization.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Have to preview or it may be difficult to understand what professor says.
professor will try to use many example to explain the theory.
He loves students asking questions.
reviews.comment_grading: Midterm exam (25%); Final exam (35%); Group project (30%); Class participation (10%)
reviews.comment_workload:
so many reading.
there is one or two readings in every class and topic and he requires us to read them all before having the midterm and final.  
there is a project and we have to do any topic about globalization.

reviews.author: Kapricornus
reviews.title: A lots of reading
reviews.comment_content: This course talks about the theories about globalization and international political economy, and how it generates recurrent economic crises within the global economic structure.
reviews.comment_teaching: The prof would ask us questions and he likes us to asking him questions ( there is 10% of participation marks in asking the questions.
reviews.comment_grading: Midterm exam (25%); Final exam (35%); Group project (30%); Class participation (10%)
reviews.comment_workload:
one group project and lots of reading and reading and reading...
it's very difficult for those didn't familiar with the topic like history to take this course, and it is hard to understand what the PPT presented to us.  the words from PPT is not logical

reviews.author: jonathan__09
reviews.comment_content: The content is pretty new to me so instead of just memorising, you need to understand some concepts in order to understand what's happening, especially in class.
reviews.comment_teaching: David is a fun professor that is very willing to teach and interact with students, just remember don't talk or play with your phone in class and don't be late!
reviews.comment_grading: It's surprising that I actually got an A range since I'm not the typical hardworking student(didn't read any of the readings), so I'd say as long as you attend most lessons and studied a bit before midterms and exams you'd definitely be alright.
reviews.comment_workload: Nothing heavy, midterm is MC, final is in essay form, and a group project where you have to hand in a paper and present in front of the class.

reviews.author: Sel123
reviews.comment_content: First half includes general topics about globalisation and second half is about globalisation in China.
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor explains things in details and relates the topics to current things happening in the world. He is open to students asking questions. Teaches using ppt slides the whole lesson. Always invite guest speakers.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading is Fair I think, can’t be too sure as we don’t know the score of the final exam and project.
Mid term was hard, it really required you to remember really small details from ppt slides and readings.
Mid term Mean : 49
I was one sd above mean.
final mean: not known and final score also not known
Final exam was not hard as we were already given the questions to prepare in advance and the same questions appeared in the final.
Group project and presentation score: also not known
Not hard to do as topics are not complicated.
Final grade: A- ( I just spent one day before the mid term and exam to go through the slides, so I think it’s not too hard to get good grade if you work a bit hard before tests. )
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is Acceptable. There  is one mid term and one final exam. There is a group project as well, where you need to write a 12 page report and do a presentation on any topic related to globalisation. You can choose the topic by yourself. If you have good group members workload is not too heavy for project. There are readings for each class, we are recommended to read them but not everyone did. So if you read all the readings, then workload can be quite a lot. But I think it’s still okay not to do the readings if you have read the PowerPoint slides thoroughly as they always include important parts of the readings.

reviews.author: krisyyk
reviews.title: Good introductory course if you are interested in Political Economy
reviews.comment_content: A little bit wide in content, it covers the basic concepts of globalization, then extending to finance, economics, politics, energy, education, culture.After mid-term the content will concentrate in China, like open and reform,  Belt and Road Initiatives etc.
reviews.comment_teaching: I should say Pro.Zweig is a nice professor! He is welcome to answer your questions and gives very appropriate suggestion for the group project. Sometimes he will invite some professors from other universities to give a guess lecture.
reviews.comment_grading:
Attendance is counted in final grade.
Mid-term contains MC and true or false question, it is extremely hard! Maybe it is the first time for Pro. Zweig to teach the course and write the exam question.
Final contains short answers and an essay, Pro. Zweig will prepare some questions for you before the exam, just finding all the answers for it  and memorize it, you will be fine.
A group project is also included, 4 to 6 groupmates have to finish 15 pages long essay and do a presentation.
I got slightly higher than mean in mid-term, Pro. Zweig was statisfied with my group's presentation :) not sure about my final, I tried my best to write as long as possible.
I got a A- in total. If you spend enough time in revision, seriously finished the group project and at least do a skim-reading in reading material, it should be fine.
reviews.comment_workload:
No any extra assignment.
For mid-term, dealing with tons of reading will be exhausted for most of us. Just hang on.
For final, it is easier than mid-term as you can prepare the answers according to the question list.
Find a turst groupmate for your group project, the workload for group project isn't too heavy in my opinion.

reviews.author: damn life
reviews.comment_content: about different economic globalisation around China, many required reading materials after each lessons, which most appeared in the mid-term and final.
reviews.comment_teaching: well, Zweig is a very good professor I teaching, with high passion in teaching, stern to students, no chitchat and eating in the class, otherwise, would be scold by Zweig. But he is a very nice professor, who welcomed students to ask him questions, he would answer us after brief researches.
reviews.comment_grading: the grading of the course is not really good though, but presentation and projects did help me to make my grading looks better
reviews.comment_workload: project, presentation, essay writing, attendance

reviews.author: Gladys LI
reviews.comment_content: The course is about globalization of economy, politics, society and so on(covered many aspects but prof only taught a bit of each topics in the class, students needed to read many contents in the required/optional readings.)
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof is from Korea but I think her teaching maybe a bit boring..
and her PPT is in the form of filling in the blanks.
reviews.comment_grading: actually I think grade is fair. Well I think find a foreign groupmate is important for project and presentation.
reviews.comment_workload:
i am a year one student and i think worload is a bit heavy.
it has  a mid term and final( MC AND FILL IN THE BLANKS)
group project and presentation( also need to write an essay)
attendance(random)

it has optional readings but it will appear in   the exams so i think it is necessary to read it.

reviews.author: ast_
reviews.title: Project is very important
reviews.comment_content: The first midterm is quite difficult while the second one is reasonable if you have memorize her slides. The project is very important as it occupies the largest percentage. Grading is relatively fine but don't expect to have great teaching.
reviews.comment_teaching: Her teaching is relatively bad. Always have break time and does not engage students during her lesson. Not much content delivered and does not give feedback to student's response.
reviews.comment_grading: Grading is reasonable and out of expectation. Project is recognized as very important as it contributes a lot and quizzes are manageable if you have revised her slides.
reviews.comment_workload: Only project and attend lessons to fill in the blanks in her slides.

reviews.author: VCJ
reviews.comment_content:
Course outline:
-What is globalization? Is globalization a new phenomenon?
-How do we explain globalization?
-International trade and production
-Development and inequality
-Globalization of finance
-Does globalization make the world more democratic
-Is globalization make the state obsolete
-Does globalization make the state obsolete?
-China in the globalized world and the future of globalization
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. Cho is a crazily hea lecturer, expect many videos on lecture which you can find youtube, weeks of project consultation and presentation. Fill in the blanks for lecture notes. There will also be a break in the middle of lecture, but she can still finish the lecture 10 min earlier. Not much feedback for students' answer on lecture.
reviews.comment_grading:
- Midterm exam (25%)
- Final exam (35%)
- Group project (30%)
- Class participation (10%) (by taking attendance during the 3 presentation sessions, had PRS for 1-2 times, not sure if that counts)

Low mean score for the mid-term:
Mean: 34.27/62; SD: 9.19
Challenging final examination (to me), no statistics.
Both in same format: MCs and fill in the blanks.

Got an A for the course, remember to take notes from assigned pages of readings, what she said on lecture but not on the notes will also appear on the exam. Memorizing blanks in lecture notes doesn't help much, common sense, you know.
reviews.comment_workload: Low, considering the short lecture hours. Project is important, big group size so there will be free-riders. Final exam is non-cumulative.

reviews.author: chimz
reviews.title: killing us harshly
reviews.comment_content:
three main areas:
economic globalization (for 7 weeks)
politics, e.g. terrorism
how far did China globalize?
reviews.comment_teaching:
I appreciate her being frank during class. She is not a professor urging people answering questions. However, her ppt is her own highlight of the reading material. Reading material is extremely important.

She did not address our concerns well, she always nodded, but I didn't know what she wanted to tell us.
reviews.comment_grading:
The midterm exam is so difficult that some MC options might not be from reading or PPT. It requires a lot of verbal memorisation. Grading might be good. But the course does not worth doing it. If you are not GCS people, don't force yourself going to this course.

Midterm exam stat:
Full mark: 62, mean: 34.37, s.d.: 10.51

My case:
i missed one sign-in.
all exams screwed up
-> B+
if you are aiming A-range, that's really difficult.
reviews.comment_workload:
1 midterm exam (week 6) - 25%
1 final exam - 35%
1 group project (due in study break) with presentation (week 13) - 30%
attendance (randomly taking by PRS) - 10%

*PRS for this semester (如有錯失，恕不負責):
week 6 on ideological orientation
during presentation

reviews.author: scientist123
reviews.comment_content:
the content is not very useful at all
it talks too much about the ancient globalization, which no one ever cares and they are not important
I prefer to talk more about modern society then the ancient one
reviews.comment_teaching:
prof cho, although pretty, speaks very softly.
no one could ever hear what she is saying
also, she seems a bit 'hea', playing useless videos all the time instead of teaching
reviews.comment_grading: normal grading
reviews.comment_workload:
you are required to go to the lectures as there are fill in the blanks ppt
(although the lectures are totally useless)

reviews.author: Samo
reviews.title: Understanding Globalization - Review
reviews.comment_content: Most of the content covered in this course is relatively straight-forward, which is a good thing, because it ensures that people come in to class with some sort of idea about what is happening. The course covers very relevant concepts in international economics and politics, looking at the failures of geopolitical organizations and geo-economic organizations.
reviews.comment_teaching: Very structured course and teaching, in terms of following the syllabus and staying with the content. Course is designed with the aim of real world applicability, and hence there are lots of videos/movies shown in class.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading for the course is quite bell-shaped, i.e. the means are not too high (around the 65-70-ish mark), and the exams are not that easy. They require constant understanding of what is happening in class, and following the readings, to ensure that you are aware of the supplementary information needed to support the conclusions from class.

One midterm, one quiz, and one final or an essay, based on four discussion questions on currency styles (fixed, floating, etc.). The exams/quizzes are predominantly based on class lectures and readings assigned, which means that if you follow along, you shouldn't find a problem.
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is not really high if you follow on with the course from time to time. Coming to class is suggested, but not mandatory, yet it requires you to complete all the readings on your own time, so that you stay with the class.

reviews.author: mx.ty
reviews.title: Good grades but much workload
reviews.comment_content:
Topic 1: History of Globalization
Topic 2: International Trade
Topic 3: Multinational Corporations and Global Supply Chains
Topic 4: International Migration
Topic 5: International Development
Part II Globalization and Economic Inequality
Topic 6: Globalization and Peace
Topic 7: Globalization and Democracy
Topic 8: Globalization and the Coronavirus Pandemic

These are the topics that he goes through with us. Some of them are interesting, for example, globalization and economic inequality. He introduced different theories to explain inequality. However, the last few topics are so boring.
reviews.comment_teaching: He really makes an effort to teach students. He asked students how he could improve his teaching. He has a Chinese accent, but it's not a big deal. Also, he would send the PowerPoint to students, and all the things he mentioned in class are included in the PowerPoint.
reviews.comment_grading:
Participation (25%)
Response Paper (25%)
Final Exam (50%)

He did not give back the response paper or final exam grade, but I got an A+ at last. All I hand in is LS paper, so the grading should be good.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is heavy as you need to read an essay and send him a discussion question about the essay every week. The essay is around 30–40 pages. It's hard for people to read all the essays. If we exclude this, then it will be fine. You just need to answer or ask five questions and finish discussion questions every week, and then You can get all 25%.

The final exam needs you to write two essays; in four questions, choose two, and all the essay questions are about the paper you read before, so it's not hard. If you revise and read the essay, then you can get a good result.

reviews.author: jgjin
reviews.comment_content:
There is a reading material you would have to read. Its not much, but you should start reading at least before your midterm. The readings will help your exams.
Her exams are comparatively easily to other courses, somewhat confusing at the same time, but still decent.
The content itself is quite easy to understand.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. Cho's teaching is decent. She prepares powerpoints for students, but there are fill in the blanks, meaning you would have to attend the classes. She speaks fluent english and tries to engage with students.
reviews.comment_grading: Pretty good.
reviews.comment_workload: I would say the quantity of the content is pretty heavy. Because the contents easy/moderate, there is a lot to memorize/understand. There is a group project and group presentation, but its not that hard.

reviews.author: ShapeofVoice
reviews.comment_content:
Boring, blow water content
Week 1: Introduction
Week 2: History of Globalisation
Week 3: Domestic interests
Week 4: State Power
Week 5: Financial Globalisation
Week 6: Financial Crises
Week 7: Globalisation and Multinational Corporations
Week 8: International Migration
Week 9: Understanding Prosperity and Poverty
Week 10: Globalisation and Economic Inequality
Week 11: Varieties of Capitalism
Week 12: The Backlash Against Globalisation: Populism and Nationalism
Week 13: Globalisation and the Coronavirus Pandemic
reviews.comment_teaching:
Normal, professor’s English is pretty bad
+9am lesson , really really sleepy
reviews.comment_grading: Unknown, only week 2 now
reviews.comment_workload: 30 pages of reading + response paper per week , super 9 , the workload really making me wanna drop it
